qas.question: What committee has established gene nomenclature for every known human gene?
How can the gene nomenclature be accessed?

answers.text: through a database maintained by HGNC

qas.question: How many symbols does each gene have?
With what is it preferred that symbols are kept consistent with?
What type of model does the mouse play a role for?

context: Gene nomenclature has been established by the <a0_0>HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC)<a0_0/> for each known human gene in the form of an approved gene name and symbol (short-form abbreviation), which can be accessed <a1_0>through a database maintained by HGNC<a1_0/>. Symbols are chosen to be unique, and each gene has <a2_0>only one<a2_0/> symbol (although approved symbols sometimes change). Symbols are preferably kept consistent with other members of a gene family and with <a3_0>homologs in other species<a3_0/>, particularly the mouse due to its role as a <a4_0>common model<a4_0/> organism.
